questions.question: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of passing watery stools more than 4 times in the past day. On examination, the baby is alert and on pinching his skin, it goes back quickly. The infant weighs 5.7 Kg. What is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhoea in this infant?
questions.explanation: The initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhoea in infants is Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), which helps replace lost fluids and electrolytes.

questions.question: The amount of total body water (TBW) in a term neonate weighing 3 kg is approximately
questions.explanation: The amount of total body water (TBW) in a term neonate is approximately 75% of the birth weight. So, in this case, 75% of 3 kg is 2.25 litres. Note: TBW is 90% in early fetal life and becomes 60% by the end of the first year and stays the same till puberty.

questions.question: What is the clinical procedure being performed?

options.B: Femoral IV access for fluid transfusion, intraosseous fluid transfusion in shock

questions.explanation: The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia. The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation. So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route. Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 minute, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia. Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion: in the proximal tibia, 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity; distal tibia at the junction of the medial malleolus and the shaft of the tibia; and the distal one-third of the femur.

questions.question: All the following statements are true regarding zinc supplementation in children with diarrhea except:

options.A: It leads to reduced duration, severity, and recurrence of diarrhea
options.B: It reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials
options.C: Excessive zinc can cause copper deficiency syndrome
options.D: It is given at a dose of 20 mg/day for 4 weeks

questions.explanation: Zinc supplementation is usually given for a duration of 10 to 14 days. Age <6 months: 10 mg/day. Age >6 months: 20 mg/day. Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials. Excessive zinc therapy can lead to copper deficiency syndrome, hence requires the regular monitoring of plasma zinc and copper concentrations.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

options.A: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
options.B: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
options.C: Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
options.D: Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher center

questions.explanation: The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 seconds) with sunken eyes. Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy and zinc supplementation according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about reduced (low)-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS)?

options.A: It contains 20 mmol of potassium per litre
options.D: Citrate is provided to prevent or correct base deficit acidosis

questions.explanation: The total osmolarity of low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is 245 mmol/L, and it is the most commonly used ORS. Potassium is provided to replace the large potassium losses, thus preventing serious hypokalemia. Citrate corrects base-deficit acidosis. Glucose promotes the absorption of sodium and water in the small intestine.

questions.question: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is
questions.explanation: Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium. Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium-potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

questions.question: A 2-year-old child weighing 7 Kg presents to the emergency with a history of vomiting and diarrhea for the last 3 days. On examination, the skin pinch over the anterior abdominal wall goes quickly to its original position. What is the interpretation of the skin pinch test in this child?

options.D: Skin pinch cannot be evaluated in this child

questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the child is malnourished, so the skin pinch cannot be evaluated. The child is of age 2 years, and the expected weight is 12 Kg. But, the weight of the child here is 7 Kg, which suggests that the child is malnourished. The child may be having edematous malnutrition (kwashiorkor), where skin may go back to the original position even in the presence of dehydration. Hence, the skin pinch is not reliable for the assessment of dehydration in this child. Reliable indicators of dehydration in the malnourished child include eagerness to drink, cool and moist extremities, weak radial pulse, and reduced urine flow.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most dangerous type of dehydration?
questions.explanation: Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration.Hypernatremia causes movement of water from brain cells into hypertonic extracellular fluid,causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within brain. This leads to centralnervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causesmovement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema,seizures, brain herniation, and even death.

questions.question: What is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through a peripheral vascular line in a neonate?
questions.explanation: Through a peripheral vascular line, a maximum of 12.5% dextrose can be infused. The dextrose concentration greater than 12.5% has an acidic pH and can cause irritation to the peripheral veins, which can lead to thrombophlebitis. Note: Central vein lines can be used for 25% D if needed.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of shock in children?
questions.explanation: Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock in children.Cardiogenic shock: cardiac pump failure due to cardiomyopathies, myocarditis or congenital heartdiseases.Hypovolemic shock: loss of body fluid due to diarrhea, vomiting or hemorrhage.Obstructive shock: mechanical barrier which obstructs the cardiac outflow like pericardialtamponade, tension pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism.177Septic shock: It is the combination of hypovolemic (intravascular fluid loss because of capillaryleak) and cardiogenic shock (because of myocardial depression by circulating inflammatorymediators) in association with infection.

questions.question: A 3-year-old baby was brought by his parents to the ER. The parents complained that thechild had been lethargic for a few hours and unresponsive for the past 30 mins. They give ahistory of 4-5 episodes of vomiting in the past one day. On examination, the baby hadtachycardia, tachypnea, and very slow capillary refill time. The pediatrician asks you toinitiate IV fluid therapy with a 24G IV cannula. Which colour IV cannula would you use?
questions.explanation: The color of the 24 G cannula is yellow. 24 G cannula is usually used for paediatric age group.
